Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the synthesis procedure for Co-MSCs. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a-c) TEM images of Co-SiO2. (d-f) SEM images of the precursor of Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–2. (g-i) TEM images of the pyrolytic Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–2 precursor. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a-c) TEM images of Co-MSC-2. (d-f) HR-TEM images of the fine structure of the Co-MSC-2 catalyst. (g) EDX maps, C element (green), O element (yellow), Co element (red) of Co- MSC-2. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of (a-c) Co-MSC-1 and (d-f) Co-MSC-3 at different magnifications. Department of Chemical and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Southeast University ChengXian College Nanjing 210088 China Carbon-supported metal oxide catalysts are highly important for heterogeneous catalysis. In addition to exciting charge transfer and regulating the electronic structure of the active metal component, the interfacial interaction between carbon and oxide can also affect the adsorption/desorption of reactants. Thus, the construction of electronic metal-support interactions for fine-tuning the performance and selectivity of the resulting heterogeneous catalysts has received widespread attention in recent years. Herein, a one-pot strategy is used to fabricate a novel porous carbon-metal oxide catalyst by pyrolyzing a Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74 composite precursor and etching the SiO2 template. Notably, tunable carbon channels with encapsulated cobalt clusters are formed in situ, and a defined strong electronic interaction between them is demonstrated. Owing to the strong interfacial interaction in this unique microreactor, cobalt oxide clusters can be anchored in a highly dispersed state to provide hierarchical carbon pores and promote charge transfer from the carbon channel to the metal sites. This process leads to enhanced reactant adsorption and activation, thereby promoting the catalytic activity of C-H bond oxidation in toluene. Under optimized conditions, Co-MSC-2 afforded 28 % conversion of toluene and 96 % selectivity for benzaldehyde, and the catalyst maintained remarkable stability. Our research proposes a new type of strong electronic oxide-carbon interaction for developing effective catalysts for C-H bond oxidation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Carbon-supported metal oxide Strong metal-support interaction Metal-organic framework C-H bond oxidation Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Selective C-H bond oxidation plays an extremely important role in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, pesticides, dyes, and optoelectronic materials [1]. For example, the selective oxidation of saturated sp3 C-H bonds in toluene is an important step for obtaining valuable oxygen-containing synthetic building blocks such as corresponding ketones or carboxylic acids. Many efforts have been made to develop heterogeneous catalysts for this transformation, especially via the ‘green chemistry’ approach, which is based on the use of molecular oxygen as the oxidant. In recent years, most studies have focused on transition metal complexes, molecular sieves, carbon nanotubes and peroxidase enzymes [2–5]. Although these catalysts exhibit efficient catalytic oxidation performance, their complex structure and indistinct active sites restrict their sustainable development. Moreover, the activation of inert saturated C-H bonds and O2 molecules involves harsh reaction conditions, such as high temperatures and high pressures. More importantly, the efficiency of the oxidation of sp3 C-H bonds is further limited by the gas-liquid-solid reaction interface. The traditional heterogeneous catalytic interface design in which catalysts are dissolved or submerged in a reaction solvent is optimal for reactions that involve only homogeneous reactants. The limited solubility and sluggish diffusion kinetics of O2 molecules in reaction solutions strongly delay the subsequent activation process at the heterogeneous reaction interface [6]. Additionally, these systems are hampered by poor mass transfer and insufficient chances for diffusion to the active sites. Both the nanostructure and active site design of the catalyst significantly affect the formation and distribution of products. Thus, to further promote C-H bond oxidation with high selectivity, advanced catalysts should comprise both definite active sites for lowering the reaction energy barriers and high-throughput reaction interfaces, which promote the activation and mass transfer of gas-liquid reactants. Supported metal catalysts have been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis because of their high degree of atomic utilization and reusability. Recent studies have shown that the support interacts strongly with metals rather than acting solely as a carrier, showing a type of strong metal-support interfacial interaction [7,8]. This interaction is considered one of the most important factors in heterogeneous catalysis because it is the key factor in improving the catalytic performance. One particular characteristic of metal-support interfaces is that they can induce electronic metal-support interactions (EMSIs) through charge redistribution at the interface [9]. This can regulate the unoccupied d states of metal active sites and efficiently promote reactant adsorption and activation to improve catalytic performance. Many studies have explored active metal-support interfaces to achieve the desired catalytic performance for different reactions, and various active interfaces have been constructed [10–12]. Notably, the active interface can be used as an active site to activate O2 and generate reactive oxygen species, such as O2 -, O2 2-, and O- [13]. The activation of O2 is a rate-determining step in gas-liquid-solid heterogeneous catalytic oxidation processes. For example, Au/TiO2 and M/CeO2 (M = Ru, Rh, Pd, or Ir) catalytic interfaces were developed for CO oxidation [14,15]. Effective electron transfer between the metal and support promotes the formation of an electron-rich interface. This increases the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules and is conducive to the oxidation of CO. Similarly, the Pt/SiO2 interface for HCHO oxidation [16], the Ag/ZSO-Y interface for ammonia oxidation [17] and the Pt/CuO interface for methanol oxidation [18] also increase the efficiency of the catalytic reactions. However, since less research effort has been devoted to the study of EMSI effects at catalytic interfaces for C-H oxidation, our understanding of how the active interface is formed in such catalysts, how it influences particle size and dispersion, and how it ultimately enhances catalytic performance is still limited. Therefore, the construction of an appropriate metal-support interface to achieve EMSIs is important for developing efficient C-H bond oxidation catalysts. Generally, the support plays an important role in the effects of the above interfaces, including interfaces between metals, reducible metal oxides (e.g., TiO2, CeO2, and CuO) and carbon materials (e.g., graphene, graphdiyne and porous carbon) [19–21]. In particular, the interfacial interactions between a carbon support and metals have been widely studied in catalytic reactions. A carbon support can not only increase the stability and dispersity of metal particles but also play an important role in heterogeneous catalysis and exert a critical effect on the catalytic efficiency. Charge transfer between carbon and a metal efficiently promotes electron delocalization and adjusts the d-band center of the metal sites to form the EMSI effect. The change in the metal d-band center, that is, the redistribution of electrons over the metal nanoparticles, results in a change in the binding energy with reaction intermediates, thus facilitating the adsorption, activation, and desorption of reactants[22]. This phenomenon is more pronounced for C-H bond oxidation, which is more sensitive to reactive oxygen species, and should be maximized to construct a suitable active interface. However, the reported support materials have low specific surface areas and poor pore structures, which are extremely unfavorable to the mass transfer process of the catalytic reaction. Traditional metal species, which are prone to aggregation or loss on supports, tend to result in low catalytic activity. Therefore, developing carbon-supported catalysts with high dispersion and rich porous structures for C-H bond oxidation is still highly desirable. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of crystalline and nanoporous materials, can provide a large surface area, high porosity, and flexible functionalities and are an ideal platform for heterogeneous catalytic oxidation [23,24]. Moreover, owing to their multiple adjacent and highly dispersed active metal centers, MOFs have high electron transfer efficiency and accessibility of catalytic sites, which is beneficial for catalytic reactions. Additionally, the well-defined active centers in MOFs help elucidate the reaction mechanism and optimize the reaction conditions. For example, Shen et al. [25] investigated the confined catalytic domains and staged oxidation sites on 2D metalloporphyrin metal-organic frameworks with bimetallic active centers. These authors reported that a lower reaction temperature reduced disordered autoxidation and inhibited the diffusion of free radical intermediates in confined catalytic domains, as well as that the second metal site, Cu(II), could also increase C-H bond oxidation. For another example, Khoo et al. [26] prepared a Zr-MOF with an ith topology consisting of Zr9 nodes, which exhibited significantly enhanced activity and selectivity toward the photocatalytic oxidation of toluene. Interestingly, other similar works on MOF catalysts reported good oxidation performance toward C-H bonds [27]. However, these catalytic systems still suffer from instability, with channel collapse and metal node loss occurring during the reaction process. In recent years, fabricating carbon-metal composites by the carbonization of MOFs at high temperatures has emerged as a new strategy to prepare homogeneously distributed metal oxide nanoparticles in a highly porous carbon matrix [28]. This structural transformation significantly improves the thermal and chemical stability of the catalyst and alters the mass transfer process of the catalytic reaction. Recently, metal-support interactions have been established through the pyrolysis of MOFs, driven by the energy release of organic ligands during decomposition [29–31]. As a typical example, Wu et al. synthesized Ru nanoparticles that are firmly attached to a carbon support derived from the carbonization of MOFs with enhanced activity for hydrogen evolution owing to the EMSI effect [32]. Although considerable work has been devoted to achieving carbon catalysts derived from MOFs with the EMSI effect, a general strategy that can unite high catalytic performance and orderly porous structures/confined mass transfer space has rarely been developed. Therefore, constructing a suitable reaction space with tunable interfacial effects in MOF-derived carbon materials remains a highly necessary yet challenging task. In this work, we prepared a series of precursor composites consisting of the porous metal SiO2 (termed Co-SiO2) as a template and Co-MOF-74 as a shell and then carbonized them to obtain the target metal-carbon porous catalysts. The goal was to construct a tunable carbon channel with encapsulated cobalt clusters, thus forming a microreactor that can promote the diffusion, adsorption, and activation of reaction molecules. Moreover, in this microreactor, both the metal sites and support were formed in situ by a one-pot method through pyrolysis of the precursor composites, which offered a unique structure with a tunable metal cluster size and a hierarchical carbon channel, and metal-support interactions were established for Co3O4 cluster on an organic linker-based carbon support. Using detailed characterization techniques such as powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and N2 adsorption-desorption, we confirmed that the carbon substrates have highly dispersed Co nanoclusters encapsulated in order carbon channel arrays. The results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Raman spectroscopy analysis further demonstrated that the introduced carbon defects provide more sites within the carbon channel to generate firm Co-C bonds, which promote tuning of the electronic structure of Co clusters by strong electronic oxide-carbon interactions. Catalytic performance evaluation and density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the strong Co-C interaction facilitated the activation of both O2 and reactants, leading to a significant improvement in C-H bond oxidation performance. Additionally, the possible catalytic mechanisms were systematically investigated. Our work bridges the gap between the EMSI effect and mass transfer regulation in the C-H bond oxidation reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and characterizations The details of the chemical reagents and catalyst characterizations are listed in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of Co-SiO2 First, 0.725 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and 0.216 g of Co(NO3)2∙6 H2O were dissolved in 100 mL of ethanol, which was named solution A. Then, 0.300 g of cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) was added to solution B, which consisted of 81.80 mL of water, 10.20 mL of ethanol, and 14.40 mL of ammonia. Subsequently, solution B was poured into solution A under continuous stirring, and after 10 min, 0.934 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added to the above solution and stirred at room temperature for 48 h. After the reaction, the solid was collected by centrifugation, washed with a water/ethanol mixture until it was colorless, and dried at 100 °C for 24 h. The solid powder was crystallized at 550 °C for 6 h in a furnace to obtain the final product. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Co-MSC To prepare of the precursor Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74 composite, in a typical procedure, 0.300 g of the obtained Co-SiO2 was dispersed as seeds in a solution of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), ethanol and H2O (at a ratio of 1:1:1 by volume). Then, 1.500 g of PVP was added, and the mixture was vigorously stirred. After 30 min, 0.476 g of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC, 2.4 mmol) and 2.305 g of Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (7.92 mmol) were added to the former solution under stirring. The above solution was transferred to a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave and heated in an oven at 150 °C for 24 h. Finally, the obtained reddish brown solid was collected by centrifugation, washed with methanol/H2O three times, and dried under vacuum at 120 °C for 12 h; the resulting mixture was named Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–2. The relationship between carbon-shell thickness and the H4DOBDC: Co2+ molar ratio was investigated by varying the ratio from 1:1–3:1. The resulting samples were labeled Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–1 and Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–3, respectively. In a typical carbonization process, the Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74 precursor was placed in a muffle furnace at 800 °C for 3 h in an air atmosphere and heated at a rate of 5 °C/min. The residual metal oxides and SiO2 were removed with 10 % sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and 5 % hydrofluoric acid (HF), respectively. The samples were then washed with deionized water, dried under vacuum at 150 °C and labeled Co-MSC-1, Co-MSC-2, or Co-MSC-3. 2.3 Evaluation of catalytic oxidation C-H bond oxidation experiments were performed to investigate the performance of different carbon catalysts. In a typical run, a certain amount of catalyst was mixed with 28 mmol of toluene and stirred for 30 min in a 50 mL sealed Schlenk tube under a flow of oxygen (0.6 MPa). Then, 10 mol% tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) was added to the solution to initiate the reaction. Within a given time interval, a certain volume of solution was quickly withdrawn, filtered with a 0.22 μm membrane and quenched with 0.5 mL of methanol. The concentrations of the oxygenated products were analyzed via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a C18 column. Nitrobenzene was used as the internal standard. All the products were referenced to standard samples. 2.4 DFT calculation The Bader charge, differential charge density and partial density of states at the interface in these carbon catalysts were studied via first-principles DFT calculations with two different models, Co3O4/defected carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and Co3O4/pristine CNTs. The detailed calculation methods are provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 illustrates the procedures for synthesizing Co-MSC via porous Co-SiO2 as the starting template. Co-MOF-74 shells of different thicknesses were epitaxially self-assembled and grown outside the template by a hydrothermal method to obtain precursor composites. The precursors were pyrolyzed in an air atmosphere and etched to obtain Co-MSCs. In this procedure, porous Co-SiO2 acted as a hard template, inducing the organic ligand (H4DOBDC) of Co-MOF-74 to generate carbon channel arrays along its pores and obtain a carbon layer. At the same time, Co coordination centers were transformed into highly dispersed Co nanocrystals and stabilized in the channel arrays by strong d-π interactions [33]. The size of these nanocrystals was adjusted during the etching process, and the Co content reached 2.80 wt% to 3.12 wt%, as measured via ICP-MS. The synergistic effect of the carbon channel arrays, highly dispersed Co sites and hierarchical porous structure promoted the mass transfer and activation process of the reaction and promoted the oxidation of C-H bonds. To obtain the above unique carbon materials, porous Co-SiO2 was first prepared and employed as the core of the precursor, which can also act as a template for the growth of channel arrays and porous carbon shells. The TEM images in Fig. 2a-c show that the synthesized Co-SiO2 had a uniform spherical structure with an average diameter of 120 nm. Moreover, abundant pore structures were identified on Co-SiO2, providing space for the formation of carbon channels during the pyrolysis process. We subsequently introduced uniform and complete layers of Co-MOF-74 on Co-SiO2 by first modifying the SiO2 in the mixed solution with PVP to fully adsorb H4DOBDC, avoiding the formation of isolated bulk MOF-74 crystals. Many aggregated Co-MOF-74 crystals were observed via SEM (Fig. 2d-f), and no obvious SiO2 spheres were observed. These images reveal the presence of SiO2 coated with the Co-MOF-74 structure in the prepared materials, confirming the successful synthesis of these precursor composites. After pyrolysis at 800 °C, the organic linkers in Co-MOF-74 were transformed into a carbon matrix, resulting in consecutive channel arrays via self-catalytic induction by metallic Co within the template pore channel. Moreover, the Co coordination centers were converted into Co nanoparticles, which acted as catalytically active sites. TEM was performed to investigate the elaborate carbon nanostructures of these materials. Fig. 2g-h shows that the structure of the Co-MOF-74 crystal collapsed after high-temperature carbonization and covered the SiO2 spheres epitaxially (marked with yellow circles). Accordingly, many large Co nanocrystals (marked with red circles in Fig. 2g) with average diameters of 50–60 nm were embedded into the multilayer carbon matrix. Notably, the zigzag edge structure observable on broken fringes of the material surface in the TEM images (Fig. 2i, marked with yellow circles) facilitates reconstruction of the local carbon lattice. This process generated diverse carbon defects, establishing a foundation for forming metal-carbon interfacial interactions between Co nanocrystals and the carbon matrix. These pyrolyzed precursors were treated with HF and H2SO4 to remove the SiO2 template and residual surface Co oxides, and further structural investigations were performed on these final as-synthesized carbon materials. The TEM images of the Co-MSC-2 sample ( Fig. 3a-c) reveal an abundance of highly ordered channel array structures, encapsulated in the carbon layer, forming a porous core-shell composite. Fig. 3d shows that the diameter of the channels was approximately 8 nm, the wall thickness was approximately 3 nm, and the thickness of the carbon shell ranged from 30 to 80 nm. Moreover, highly dispersed Co nanocrystals with an average diameter of 4 nm were still embedded into the channel arrays with strong metal-carbon interactions (Fig. 3e, marked with red circles). Compared with that before acid treatment, the Co nanocrystal size significantly decreased (Fig. 2g), indicating that the acid washing process can regulate the nanocrystal size in channels. This process endows Co nanocrystals with abundant binding sites and high catalytic activity. High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) was used to verify the detailed crystal structure of the Co nanoparticles directly. The insets of Fig. 3e and Fig. 3f show the lattice fringes of both the nanocrystalline Co and multilayer graphitic carbon structures; the d-spacing of 0.20 nm corresponds to the Co (111) planes, and the d-spacing of 0.35 nm corresponds to the C (002) planes [34]. Furthermore, carbon defects and edge structures remained inherited in the Co-MSC-2 material after etching and acid treatment (marked with a yellow circle in Fig. 3f), indicating that these unique nanostructures were preserved during carbonization. Elemental distribution analysis of Co-MSC-2 was conducted by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping. Fig. 3g shows the homogeneous distribution of C, O, and Co species over the whole area of the carbon channel structures. These results indicate that the porous carbon substrate presents outstanding advantages in the formation of cobalt clusters. The aforementioned TEM results indicate that the internal pore structure of the carbon material was formed by Co-MOF-74 organic ligand catalysis induced along the SiO2 pore as a growth template during the carbonization process. Even after the removal of SiO2 through HF etching, the fine carbon channel and carbon shell structure were maintained. This unique structure can effectively promote the mass transfer of reaction molecules in a material and increase its catalytic performance. Furthermore, to study the influence of the Co-MOF-74 layer on the formation of carbon channel and carbon shell fine structures during the pyrolysis process, precursors with H4DOBDC:Co2+ molar ratios of 1:1 or 3:1 were explored. These samples were also subjected to carbonization, etching and acid washing procedures and were named Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3. TEM was employed to compare the fine structures of the two samples, as shown in Fig. 4. Notably, carbon channel arrays and carbon shells are also present in these materials. However, unlike Co-MSC-2, Co-MSC-1 had no obvious carbon shell structure (Fig. 4a-c). This may be because an insufficient Co-MOF-74 layer completely coated SiO2 when the H4DOBDC: Co2+ molar ratio was set at 1:1, thus preventing the formation of a carbon shell during pyrolysis. For Co-MSC-3, the carbon channel array was coated with a carbon layer structure, but it was very thin. The decrease in the shell thickness of Co-MSC-3 can be attributed to Co-MOF-74 tending to form isolated bulk crystals at large molar ratios rather than to undergo epitaxial self-assembly along the SiO2 template. Fig. S1 shows SEM images of the Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–3 precursor, revealing obvious bulk Co-MOF-74 crystals, which cannot provide enough carbon sources for the formation of a carbon shell during pyrolysis. According to recent reports, the pyrolysis of Co-based MOFs allows the abundant doping of Co-carbon active sites in carbon catalysts, which significantly increases the catalytic activity for oxidation reactions [35,36]. The above TEM results demonstrated that the Co nanocrystals in the Co-MSC-2 samples are highly stable and can be further oxidized and aggregated, even at nanocluster sizes, when they are anchored in carbon channels, indicating the possibility of strong oxide-support interactions between them. However, as shown in Fig. 4, significantly fewer Co nanocrystals are present in the carbon channels of Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 than in the carbon shell. This difference can be attributed to the self-assembly of Co-MOF-74 outside SiO2 [37,38]. Thus, it is conceivable that the strong interaction between the oxides and support in these two samples is significantly reduced, which is not conducive to the activation of the reacting molecules. To investigate the structures and compositions of the as-prepared samples, we conducted a series of characterizations. PXRD was used to examine the detailed crystal nanostructure of these samples. The XRD patterns of the Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74 precursor catalysts are shown in Fig. 5a, showing intense characteristic peaks at 6.9° and 11.8°, which can be indexed to the (120) and (030) facets of Co-MOF-74 and agree with previous reports [39], demonstrating that no structural changes occurred in Co-MOF-74 after this coating was applied. Notably, the patterns of the precursors show no obvious diffraction peak for SiO2, indicating that most of the SiO2 was almost completely coated by Co-MOF-74. PXRD analyses revealed the successful preparation of the precursor composite, which was composed of a SiO2 core and a Co-MOF-74 layer. The aforementioned results also revealed that, even with variations in the molar ratio of H4DOBDC: Co(NO3)2·6H2O, the Co-MOF-74 overlayer was still able to self-assemble on the outer surface of SiO2. After the precursors were carbonized at high temperature in an air atmosphere, O2 was introduced, which allowed the Co coordinated center and organic linker to be directly converted to cobalt oxides and graphite carbon. The broad peak at 26° in the patterns (Fig. 5b) is indexed to the (002) plane of the multilayer graphitic carbon [40]. This is also verified by the lattice spacing of the graphite carbon observed via HR-TEM. Moreover, no signals for SiO2 species were found. The above results indicate that the removal of SiO2 by etching with HF yielded Co-MSC samples, which are carbon materials with unique carbon channel arrays and hierarchical carbon shell structures. The diffraction peaks at 31.3°, 36.9°, 38.6°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.4° and 65.3° can be assigned to the (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) planes of the Co3O4 phase (JCPDS No. 43–1003) [41]. This result demonstrated that Co3O4 nanocrystals were formed under an air atmosphere by pyrolysis. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 are sharper than those of Co-MSC-2 and may be attributed to the Co3O4 nanocrystals being distributed mainly in their carbon shells, which was also confirmed by TEM observations. The abundant porous structures of the prepared carbon catalysts were detected by the above characterization methods. N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were further used to determine the surface areas and pore diameters of the Co-MSC samples. On the basis of the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms shown in Fig. 6a, all the investigated Co-MSC samples exhibit typical IV isotherms with obvious H3 hysteresis loops at relative pressures between 0.5 and 0.9, indicating the presence of a mesoporous structure. In addition, the pore size distribution curves confirmed this observation, and more mesoporous structures were observed for Co-MSC-2, which are expected to benefit mass transfer and electron transport (Fig. 6b). This finding combined with the TEM results indicate that the mesoporous structure of the material is inherited from the carbon channel generated by the carbonization of organic ligands along the SiO2 channels and derived from the part connecting the carbon channel with the carbon shell structure [42]. In comparison, Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 prepared without the growth of entire carbon shells had fewer mesoporous structures. Moreover, the BET surface area and pore volume of these samples were determined via the t-plot method and are displayed in Table S1. The specific surface area of Co-MSC-2 is 148 m2/g, which is much greater than those of Co-MSC-1 (101 m2/g) and Co-MSC-3 (111 m2/g), indicating a deficiency in the core-shell structure. The above results indicate that the precise construction of precursors plays a decisive role in the formation of unique pore structures in carbon catalysts. This provides an effective pathway for mass diffusion of reactant molecules, which is beneficial for obtaining better catalytic performance. The graphitization degree of the carbon matrices in the Co-MSC samples was investigated by Raman spectroscopy, where the characteristic D band (lattice defective C atom) and G band (graphite carbon) can be clearly identified at approximately 1350 and 1580 cm−1, respectively ( Fig. 7). Therefore, the ratio of the D to G intensities (ID/IG) of a carbon matrix are important parameters for studying the graphitization degree as well as the nature of the defects in carbon materials, and the ratio increases as the degree of graphitization of amorphous carbon increases. Notably, the ID/IG values of Co-MSC-1, Co-MSC-2 and Co-MSC-3 were 1.02, 1.12 and 1.05, respectively, implying that the degree of graphitization of carbon greatly depends on the composition of the precursor structure. Co-MSC-2 clearly exhibited more defects and edge nanostructures, which can promote interactions between Co3O4 nanocrystals and the carbon channel substrate[43]. In summary, the Raman spectra provide strong evidence that high-temperature pyrolysis facilitates the formation of Co-C sites at the carbon defect-oxide interface. This interfacial regulation strategy reconstructs the electron cloud at the active sites, not only stabilizing highly dispersed Co oxides but also promoting charge transfer[44]. In contrast, the lower ID/IG values of Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 imply the formation of more conjugated sp2 C atom networks in the materials, resulting in locally ordered graphene lattices, which cannot provide sufficient metal binding sites[45]. Many studies have shown that electron transfer between metal oxides and support materials is influenced by changes in the surface properties of the support, leading to changes in the electronic structure of the active sites. Thus, XPS characterization was carried out to obtain information on their chemical states and simultaneously analyze charge transfer. As shown in Fig. 8a, the full XPS survey spectra of the Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–2 precursor reveal the presence of C, O, Si and Co species. After acid washing and HF etching, the characteristic peaks of C, O, and Co in the Co-MSC samples were still present, but the Si 2p peak with a binding energy of ∼103.08 eV disappeared, indicating that the Co-SiO2 in the precursor materials was almost completely removed by post-treatment. Fig. 8b shows the elemental contents of the Co-MSC samples, revealing a lower Co content in Co-MSC-2 (≈ 1.9 at%). In contrast, relatively high-intensity Co signals were detected for Co-MSC-1 (≈ 2.5 at%) and Co-MSC-3 (≈ 4.6 at%). The increase in Co content may be because the Co3O4 nanoclusters in Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 tend to be distributed on the material surface, whereas those in Co-MSC-2 are more anchored inside the carbon channels via an accurate carbonization process. Moreover, high-resolution XPS analysis was used to test the Co species on the as-prepared carbon catalysts ( Fig. 9a-c). The Co 2p spectra for all samples had two main characteristic peaks at approximately 781.5 and 796.6 eV, which were assigned to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 owing to spin-orbit coupling. To further prove the oxidation state of cobalt, the Co 2p1/2 peak of the samples was fitted to two peaks at approximately 781.1 and 782.9 eV, which were attributed to Co3+ and Co2+ species, respectively. Notably, for Co-MSC-2, the Co 2p1/2 peak can be fitted into an extra peak at a binding energy of 779.6 eV, indicating the presence of Co0 species in this catalyst [46]. The difference in the electronic states of the Co species was probably due to the different metal-support interactions. The Co oxide nanoclusters were confined mainly inside the carbon channels of Co-MSC-2, forming strong electronic interactions between Co oxides and carbon layers in the Co-C interface structure, where Co species can be stabilized in a low-oxidation state under ambient conditions [47]. To further prove the strong electronic interaction between Co oxides and carbon channels, the high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 9d-f. The C 1 s spectra of all the samples were split into four dominant peaks at binding energies of approximately 284.9, 285.9, 287.1 and 289.1 eV, which are indexed to C-C sp2, C-C sp, C-O, and CO coordination bonds, respectively. An additional low-intensity peak at 283.4 eV is attributed to the Co-C bond caused by the Co oxide clusters anchored in the carbon channels through strong metal-support interactions [48]. Moreover, the peaks belonging to C-C sp2 and C-C sp in Co-MSC-2 shifted toward more positive binding energies (Fig. 9e, approximately 0.4 and 0.2 eV, respectively), indicating electron transfer from carbon channels to Co nanoclusters [49], similar to the charge transfer in the strong electronic oxide-metal interactions reported in the literature [50]. The above XPS results suggest the presence of strong electronic oxide-support interactions between Co3O4 nanocrystals and carbon channels in the Co-MSC-2 material. This may be attributable to the unique structure of Co3O4 nanocrystals anchored in the carbon channels. The carbon defects of the carbon channels in Co-MSC-2 facilitate the formation of interfacial Co-C bonds by binding with Co nanoclusters. Additionally, the carbon channel substrates act as electron acceptors or donors, for which the direction and quantity of electron transfer across the interface depend on their work function differences [22]. The shift in the binding energy of carbon measured by XPS effectively reveals charge transfer across the Co-C interface. This charge redistribution enhances the activation of reactant molecules at the active sites, thereby increasing the catalytic performance. The strong electronic oxide-carbon interactions in the above carbon catalysts were further evaluated via DFT calculations. A Co3O4 nanocluster model composed of 26 Co atoms was constructed and then combined on the surface of segmented defected CNTs and pristine CNTs through Co-C bonds, representing Co-MSC-2 and Co-MSC-1 or Co-MSC-3, respectively. Fig. 10 shows the charge density redistribution and interlayer charge transfer in the optimal oxide-CNT heterostructure. These models were very stable and exhibited many negative binding energies (Fig. S2) after full relaxation. Bader charge and differential charge density analyses were subsequently performed to quantify the charge transfer between nanoclusters and CNTs. Notably, a net migration of 1.70 e occurred from the defective CNT substrate to the Co3O4 nanoclusters through Co-C bonds (Fig. 10a), implying the generation of a strong interaction across the interface, which is consistent with the experimental results discussed above. Conversely, the CNT substrate captures up to 9.76 e from the Co3O4 nanoclusters in the pristine CNT model (Fig. 10b). Interfacial charge transfer modulates the electronic structure of the active sites, significantly increasing their adsorption capacity toward reactant molecules and lowering the activation energy barrier, thereby increasing the catalytic efficiency. For Co-MSC-2, electrons are donated on the Co oxide nanoclusters, enhancing the adsorption and activation of O2 and C-H bonds [51]. However, Co oxide nanoclusters lack electrons in pristine CNTs and thus have relatively weak activation ability. We used the C-H bond oxidation of toluene to prove the ability of the carbon catalyst structure mentioned above to activate reaction molecules with strong electronic oxide-support interactions. Solvent screening showed that the best conversion of benzaldehyde was still obtained under nonsolvent conditions (Table S2, entries 1–5). Oxidation occurs in other solvents, such as methanol, acetonitrile, dioxane and cyclohexane, resulting in a lower conversion of toluene or selectivity for benzaldehyde. The choice of free radical initiator had a significant effect on the oxidation reaction (Table S2, entry 6), and TBHP was superior to H2O2. Compared with the addition of the same amount of TBHP in one portion, the addition of 10 mol% TBHP three times increased the conversion (Table S2, entry 7). Moreover, an appropriate oxygen pressure is conducive to facilitating the progression of the reaction (Table S2, entry 8). Under the optimized conditions, toluene and Co-MSC-2 were sealed in a 50 mL Schlenk tube that was outgassed completely, purged with O2, and the mixture was suspended for 6 h. Under these conditions, benzaldehyde was obtained by toluene oxidation with 28 % conversion and 96 % selectivity ( Table 1, entry 1). A small amount of benzyl alcohol and unreacted toluene were also detected, and almost no benzoic acid was generated. Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 were also applied to this oxidation reaction, converting toluene with conversions of only 22 % and 26 %, respectively, and affording benzaldehyde selectivity of 87 % and 81 % under standard conditions (Table 1, entries 2 and 3), respectively. In comparison, when the Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74–2 precursor was used, the oxidation reaction occurred with a relatively low conversion (Table 1, entry 4, 13 %), which was similar to the result reported in our previous work [52] (toluene conversion of 12 %). This finding verified the importance of the unique structural carbon catalyst in the C-H bond oxidation reaction, which may be attributed to the superior activation ability of the reactant molecules at the Co-C interface as the catalytic center. Moreover, after the reaction, Co-MSC-2 could be easily recycled by simple centrifugation without further activation, and there was no significant decline in performance within six cycles (<4 %, Fig. 11a). In addition, the PXRD (Fig. 11b), SEM (Fig. 11c) and TEM (Fig. 11d and e) results confirmed that the structure and morphology of the reused Co-MSC-2 were maintained during the oxidation process, which may be attributable to the robust core-shell structure. The migration of metal active centers is another key issue that hinders the activity of heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, leaching experiments were carried out to determine whether Co species are lost from the carbon support during the oxidation reaction. ICP-MS measurements revealed trace Co2+ leaching from Co-MSC-2 after one reaction (Fig. S3). However, the degree of Co leaching in both Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3 was relatively high. Additionally, after the reaction proceeded for 3 h, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation. The reaction of the filtrate continued for another 3 h, and no change in the conversion of toluene was observed (Fig. 11f). The results of this filtration test implied that Co nanoclusters in Co-MSC-2 are anchored inside the carbon channels and stabilized by strong Co-C bonds, effectively preventing the loss of active species during the reaction. Control experiments suggest that both the carbon catalysts and TBHP are necessary for C-H bond oxidation (Table 1, entries 5 and 6) and that reactions with low conversions or that almost no reactions occur without the catalyst or TBHP. When N2 is used instead of O2 at the same pressure, only trace background autoxidation products can be detected (Table 1, entry 7). Decreasing the catalyst content from 20 mg to 10 mg led to a slight decrease in conversion, but the selectivity for benzaldehyde remained unchanged (Table 1, entry 8). This decrease in catalytic activity may be attributable to the decrease in the number of active sites in the reaction system, which reduces the activation ability of the reactants. In addition, when the reaction occurs at room temperature (Table 1, entry 9), toluene can still be converted to the corresponding oxygenated products, which indicates that the Co-C active sites can activate reactants at a lower temperature. Table S3 compares our work with several recently reported studies. Although the Co-MSC-2 catalyst results in a lower toluene conversion than the homogeneous catalyst NHPI does, it achieves significantly higher benzaldehyde selectivity (Table S3, entry 1). Other metal catalysts, such as V4AlC3 MAX, CeO2-MnOx, and TeOx/MoVTeNbO, have similar or lower oxidation efficiencies for toluene than Co-MSC-2 (Table S3, entries 2–4). Under relatively mild reaction conditions, supported catalysts such as Pt1/B-TiO2, MEO@rGO and 0.03Au@Silicalite-1 also demonstrate favorable efficiency for toluene oxidation (Table S3, entries 5–9). However, these systems struggle to balance high conversion with selectivity regulation. Therefore, our catalyst with strong Co-C interactions achieves notable progress in terms of overall performance, with both toluene conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity. To further explain how strong Co-C interactions affect the catalytic performance and to determine the C-H bond oxidation mechanism of Co-MSC-2, adsorption/desorption experiments were first conducted via FT-IR measurements. As shown in Fig. S4a, the stretching vibration peak at 1325–1550 cm−1 for toluene indicated that all these carbon materials can adsorb toluene molecules. Notably, the peak intensity of the Co-MSC-2 samples was much stronger than that of Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3. This obvious difference confirms the preferential adsorption of toluene on Co-MSC-2, which agrees well with the evaluation experiments. After toluene adsorbs into the unique carbon channel microreactor of Co-MSC-2, the most plausible activation pathway is the hydrogen abstraction mechanism involving free radicals [53]. Thus, a control experiment was designed through the addition of the radical scavenger 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine 1-oxyl (TEMPO) during the standard oxidation step. The oxidation reaction was prevented (Table S2, entry 9), suggesting that toluene was triggered and converted into benzyl radicals ( Fig. 12) by the free radical generated by TBHP. The above experiments and results from the literature indicate that the oxygen that was inserted into the above benzyl species should react with the reactive oxygen species, which are also activated by the Co-C active sites. The strong Co-C interaction probably originates from the hybridization of the 3d orbitals of Co with the 2p orbitals of the defected carbon channels, which not only stabilizes Co oxide nanoclusters but also promotes the transfer of electrons to the adsorbed O2. As the initial state of the catalyst, O2 was activated by a CoII center of oxide nanoclusters and produced CoIII-O-O•− species, which further react with benzyl radicals to generate a Ph-CH2-O-O-CoII intermediate (II) (Fig. 12). This peroxide intermediate formed another active species, CoIII=O (III), through O-O bond homolytic cleavage and then released a benzyloxy radical. Benzyloxy radicals capture H· to form the oxygen-containing product benzyl alcohol, which is further oxidized to aldehyde as the final product. Notably, although benzaldehyde is thermodynamically prone to oxidation to benzoic acid, no benzoic acid was detected in this system. This may be because benzyl alcohol, as an intermediate in the reaction, can intercept the formation of peroxy radicals through the hydrogen atom transfer mechanism, thereby blocking the excessive oxidation of benzaldehyde and inhibiting the generation of benzoic acid [54,55]. On the other hand, CoIII=O reacts directly with toluene to give CoII-OH and benzyl radicals (IV). This reactive radical is converted to benzyl alcohol through a radical rebound process and is ultimately oxidized to the aldehyde product [56]. Then, Co sites can also activate oxygen and transform back to the initial CoIII (I) state. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Co 2p after the reaction demonstrated almost no change in the cobalt valence state distribution compared with that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. S5), which confirmed the reversible valence transition of Co sites during the catalytic process. In addition, we measured the desorption of toluene from each catalyst (Fig. S4b). The characteristic peak almost disappeared when the temperature was increased to 80 °C, indicating that toluene is easier to desorb from Co-MSC-2 than from Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3, which verifies its higher selectivity for benzaldehyde. To gain a deeper understanding of the effects of strong electronic oxide-carbon interactions on the catalytic activity, partial density of state (PDOS) calculations of surface Co atoms for the reaction were performed by DFT computational methods. As shown in Fig. 13a and b, the Co d-band center in defected CNTs (-1.409 eV) is closer to the Fermi energy level than that in pristine CNTs (-1.465 eV), indicating that Co3O4 nanoclusters exhibit enhanced intrinsic performance in Co-MSC-2 compared with Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3. Furthermore, when a toluene molecule adsorbs on the nanoclusters, the d-band center of Co shifts from −1.409 eV to −1.357 eV in the defected CNTs, whereas a small negative shift from −1.465 eV to −1.496 eV is observed in the pristine CNTs. The closer the d-band center is to the Fermi level, the more reactive the catalysts are. Thus, after the adsorption of toluene, the upshift in the Co d-band center in Co-MSC-2 indicates that more electrons enriched on Co atoms in the interface structure promote the formation of Co-π complexes with toluene during the catalytic process [49]. Compared with the case of a positive shift, fewer electrons are distributed on the Co atoms in Co-MSC-1 and Co-MSC-3, which is not conducive to the subsequent adsorption and activation of toluene. Therefore, all the above experiments and DFT calculations clearly show that moderately strong electronic oxide-carbon interactions facilitate the oxidation of toluene through regulating the electronic structure of surface Co atoms and providing enough active sites, which in turn promotes the mass transfer behavior of the reactants to promote toluene conversion. 4 Conclusion In summary, a sequence of Co-MSC nanocatalysts derived from MOF precursors with a novel type of strong electronic oxide-carbon interaction in carbon channel-supported cobalt oxide nanocluster catalysts was prepared. Using one-pot pyrolysis, template etching and acid washing, we successfully obtained a fine carbon channel array with a carbon shell structure and cobalt oxide nanoclusters with tunable sizes. The unique geometric structure of the catalyst facilitates mass transfer to expose abundant readily accessible active sites. More importantly, the electron transfer between the carbon channel and nanocluster was systematically studied, and the results demonstrated that the interfacial Co-C bonds played a crucial role in charge transfer. This strong electronic oxide-carbon interaction can induce a charge to concentrate on Co3O4 nanoclusters, which promotes the adsorption of reactant molecules and facilitates their activation. The resulting Co-MSC-2 catalyst exhibited apparent catalytic performance toward C-H bond oxidation, and the optimized conditions achieved toluene conversion of 28 % and benzaldehyde selectivity of 96 %. This study highlights the importance of the interfacial effect in modulating the catalytic activity of porous carbon materials for heterogeneous catalysis and provides a route for constructing strong oxide-carbon interactions to elucidate the structure-activity relationship for broader applications of carbon catalysts for C-H bond oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Carbon-supported metal oxide catalysts are highly important for heterogeneous catalysis. In addition to exciting charge transfer and regulating the electronic structure of the active metal component, the interfacial interaction between carbon and oxide can also affect the adsorption/desorption of reactants. Thus, the construction of electronic metal-support interactions for fine-tuning the performance and selectivity of the resulting heterogeneous catalysts has received widespread attention in recent years. Herein, a one-pot strategy is used to fabricate a novel porous carbon-metal oxide catalyst by pyrolyzing a Co-SiO2@Co-MOF-74 composite precursor and etching the SiO2 template. Notably, tunable carbon channels with encapsulated cobalt clusters are formed in situ, and a defined strong electronic interaction between them is demonstrated. Owing to the strong interfacial interaction in this unique microreactor, cobalt oxide clusters can be anchored in a highly dispersed state to provide hierarchical carbon pores and promote charge transfer from the carbon channel to the metal sites. This process leads to enhanced reactant adsorption and activation, thereby promoting the catalytic activity of C-H bond oxidation in toluene. Under optimized conditions, Co-MSC-2 afforded 28 % conversion of toluene and 96 % selectivity for benzaldehyde, and the catalyst maintained remarkable stability. Our research proposes a new type of strong electronic oxide-carbon interaction for developing effective catalysts for C-H bond oxidation.
